ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
I'd say a cross between live virtual lecture and virtual seminar, since class was modeled off a powerpoint lecture but we were able to have discussions and ask questions in real time.
The class was interactive and students were often called upon to answer questions or offer insights.
No other modes

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the basics of the Navy and how different aspects of it operate. The structure of the Navy, including ranks and platforms were covered appropriately.
I learned about the fundamentals of the Navy.

This was a solid introduction to certain elements of the Navy. In particular, I thought learning about the different types of platforms and officer communitiessurface, subs, aviationwas helpful. Familiarizing ourselves with some of the customs as well as the officer/enlisted manuals was also helpful.

I learned a lot of useful knowledge that will prepare me for a career in the Navy. Additionally, I learned what being a naval officer is like and how officership contributes to the many missions and goals of the US Navy.

I learned about the structure of the Navy and the US military as a whole, the various line communities within the Navy, customs and courtesies, safety procedures, and the values of the Navy among other topics. I gained insight into what it is like to serve in the Navy and what it means to be a naval officer. I also gained confidence and practice speaking in front of my classmates.
I learned the basics about the Navy.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Over Zoom, talking about a class that can largely be memorized, there is only so much engagement that can happen. This is especially true when the class is held at 7:30 in the morning. LT Melvin is a great instructor and does his best to liven up the content, but when even he is suggesting that the course is rather dry, there is an upper bound on how enjoyable a class can be. I would say the course is as strong as it can be given the circumstances and the content, and LT Melvin makes the course as strong as it can be.
LT Melvin is an awesome teacher and he did the absolutely best job he could, but the early-morning + virtual + lecture format really makes the material boring.

LT Melvin was organized with his material and engaging as an instructor; this was a great class to have bright and early. Don't take this the wrong way, and I absolutely mean it as a complement, but LT Melvin was very entertaining (while still being professional) and the class was a lot of fun when it could just as easily been really dry. 

I realize this was an introduction, but I would have liked to have been able to learn more; that being said, it was nice that the course was not too dense and the relaxed pacing was nice for making sure the most important material was emphasized.
Strengths: knowledgeable and engaging professor; interesting and valuable material
Strengths: instructor did a good job making sure everyone contributed to the class discussion.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom is just no replacement for in-person instruction. Synchronous Zoom and asynchronous testing is a fine model given the circumstances, but I would have obviously preferred to meet socially-distant and in-person.
LT Melvin asking questions to the class, showing videos, and interspersing the material with anecdotes helped the class.
I thought LT Melvin did a great job, and I was excited to hear from some of the other officers about their communities.
The zoom lectures were very effective and student engagement and presentations were effective as well.
Not much can be improved, giving the virtual learning circumstances.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is required for NROTC, so obviously I recommend that everyone who needs to take it. For those who do not need to take it but are considering a Naval career, this course is a solid intro to the community.
I would recommend this course if you are thinking of joining the Armed Forces.

It's required for midshipmen, but yes I would recommend to anyone who is curious about the Navy. The workload is really light, and for students considering the program this course could be a helpful introduction without adding much to a packed Yale schedule.
Yes
No, its really only needed for students interested in pursuing a Naval career.
